DataElement.preferredName: Biospecimen Adrenal Gland Anatomic Subsite Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The location of the adrenal gland from which the specimen was collected.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. Biospecimen can contain one or more components including but not limited to cellular molecules, cells, tissues, organs, body fluids, embryos, and body excretory products._A flattened, roughly triangular body resting upon the upper end of each kidney; it is one of the ductless glands furnishing internal secretions (epinephrine and norepinephrine from the medulla and steroid hormones from the cortex)._Relating to anatomy._A position within another named site.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any material sample taken from a biological entity for testing, diagnostic, propagation, treatment or research purposes, including a sample obtained from a living organism or taken from the biological object after halting of all its life functions. PermissibleValues.value: Right, if necessary for sufficient aliquots

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The adrenal gland located on the right side of the body.

Concepts.definition: The adrenal gland located on the right side of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.: A flattened, roughly triangular body resting upon the upper end of each kidney; it is one of the ductless glands furnishing internal secretions (epinephrine and norepinephrine from the medulla and steroid hormones from the cortex).

Concepts.definition: Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.

A flattened, roughly triangular body resting upon the upper end of each kidney; it is one of the ductless glands furnishing internal secretions (epinephrine and norepinephrine from the medulla and steroid hormones from the cortex).
